facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 142 and 143 of 1963 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 13, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 142 and 143 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 13, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders No. 41 and 69 of 1959.

facts.text: The appeals were from Appeals from Original Orders No. 41 and 69 of 1959 in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 13, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders No. 41 and 69 of 1959.

facts.text: For assessment year 1947-48, appellant in Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1963 filed a return before Income-tax Officer, District IV, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1947-48 the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1963 filed a return of her income before the Income-tax Officer, District IV, Calcutta, and the assessment was companypleted sometime in 1948 as a result whereof it was found that numbertax was payable by her.

facts.text: Assessment for appellant in CA 142/1963 was completed sometime in 1948 and tax was found payable by her.

anchor.surface_text: and the assessment was companypleted sometime in 1948 as a result whereof it was found that numbertax was payable by her. on April 2, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served on her a numberice dated March 19, 1956, under s. 34 7  of the Indian Income tax Act, 1922,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer served notice dated March 19, 1956 under s.34 of 1922 Act on appellant in CA 142/1963 on April 2, 1956 for escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: on April 2, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served on her a numberice dated March 19, 1956, under s. 34 7  of the Indian Income tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act, on the ground of escaped assessment.

facts.text: The notice in CA 142/1963 was dated within 8 years from end of relevant assessment year March 31, 1948 but served beyond 8 years.

anchor.surface_text: The date of the numberice fell within 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year i.e., March 31, 1948 but it was served beyond 8 years from that date and, therefore, was clearly out of time under the provisions of the said section.

facts.text: For CA 143/1963, assessment year 1947-48, appellant assessed on total income Rs. 28,993 on December 30, 1948 by ITO.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1963, for the assessment year 1947-48 the appellant was assessed on a total income of Rs. 28,993/- on December 30, 1948, by the Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Tax amounting to Rs. 4,747-13-0 was deposited on behalf of appellant in CA 143/1963 in Reserve Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: and the tax thereon amounting to Rs. 4,747-13-0 was deposited on behalf of the appellant in the Reserve Bank of,,, India.

facts.text: Notice dated March 19, 1956 served on April 2, 1956 under s.34 on appellant in CA 143/1963 for escaped assessment, served beyond 8 years from March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On April 2, 1956, the appellant was served with a numberice dated March 19, 1956, by the Income-tax Officer purporting to be under s. 34 of the Act on the ground of escaped assessment. The date of the numberice fell within 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year, i.e., March 31, 1956 but it was served beyond 8 years from that date

facts.text: Appellants filed two petitions under Art. 226 of Constitution in Calcutta High Court for quashing the notices.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the two appeals filed two petitions in the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the said numberices and for other appropriate reliefs.

facts.text: On March 20, 1957, Sinha J. of Calcutta High Court issued rules nisi on the two applications to ITO, CIT and Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1957, Sinha, J., of that Court issued rules nisi on the said two applications to the Income-tax Officer, the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Union of India.

facts.text: On September 11, 1958, Sinha J. made the rules absolute.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1958, the said Judge made the rules absolute.

facts.text: Respondents preferred appeals from judgment of Sinha J. to Division Bench of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to the applications preferred appeals from the judgment of Sinha, J., to a Division Bench of that Court.

facts.text: On March 12, 1959, s.34 of the Act was amended by s.2 of the Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeals, on March 12, 1959, s. 34 of the Act was amended by s. 2 of the AmendinAct.

facts.text: Division Bench consisting of Bose C.J. and G. Mitter J. heard the appeals after amendment.

anchor.surface_text: After the said amendment the appeals were heard by a Division Bench of the High Court, companysisting of Bose, C. J., and G. Mitter, J.

facts.text: Division Bench held notices saved under s.4 of Amending Act, set aside orders of Sinha J., dismissed writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the said amendment the learned Judges held that the said numberices, though served on the appellants after the prescribed time, were saved under s. 4 of the Amending Act. In that view they set aside the orders of Sinha, J., and dismissed the writ petitions.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Subba Rao J. on March 31, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: March 31, 1964. anchor.surface_text: Before companystruing the section it will be useful to numberice the relevant rules of companystruction of a fiscal statute. In Oriental Bank v. Wright 1  the Judicial Committee held that if a statute professed to impose a charge, the intention to impose a charge upon a subject must be shown by clear and unambiguous language. In Canadian Eagle Oil Co. v. R., 2  Viscount Simon L. C. observed In the words of Rowlatt J in a taxing Act one has to look at what is clearly said. There is numberroom for any intendment. There is numberequity about a tax. There is numberpresump- tion as to a tax. Nothing is to be read in, numberhing is to be implied. One can only look fairly at the language used.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Issued' interpreted as equivalent to 'served' using prior judicial interpretations under s.34, Barras rule, dictionary meanings, statutory analogies, harmonious construction avoiding anomalies, and purposive intent to validate time-barred notices and proceedings.

holdings.text: s. 4 of the Amending Act cannot be described as a provision laying down the machinery for the calculation of tax... It resuscitates barred claims. Therefore, the same stringent rules of construction appropriate to a charging section shall also apply to such a provision.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the emphasis on the letter of the law, the fundamental rule of construction of a fiscal Acts would apply, and not the exception engrafted on that rule for, s. 4 of the Amending Act cannot be described as a provision laying down the machinery for the calculation of tax. In substance it enables the Income-tax Officer to reassess a persons income which has escaped assessment, though the time within which he could have so assessed had expired under the Act before the amendment of 1959. It resuscitates barred claims.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes machinery provisions (liberal construction per Gursahai Saigal) from resuscitating provisions creating new liability like charging sections (strict construction per Oriental Bank, Canadian Eagle); s.4 empowers reassessment of time-barred escaped income.

holdings.text: the expression issued used in the proviso to sub-section 3 should be equated with the expression served rather than that the expression served used in sub-section 1 should be equated with the expression issued used in the proviso to sub-section 3... This decision equated the expression issued with expression served.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the said expression has received, before the amendment, a clear judicial interpretation. Under s. 34 1 a of the Act the Income-tax Officer may in cases falling under cl. a at any time within 8 years serve on the assessee a notice... Rejecting that argument, Chagla, C. J., speaking for the Court, observed In other words, the attempt is to equate the expression served used in section 34 with the expression issued used in the proviso to sub- section 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior High Court decisions (CIT v. Ghurve, Sri Niwas) equated 'issued' with 'served' in s.34 context; legislature presumed to adopt that meaning per Barras rule.

holdings.text: Section 4 of the Amending Act of 1959, therefore, was enacted for the sole purpose of saving the validity of such notices in respect of all escaped incomes relating to any year commencing from the year ending on March 31, 1941, though they were issued beyond the prescribed time.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Amending Act of 1959 was passed, Income tax Officers issued notices before April 1, 1956, and also after that date for reopening assessments made beyond 8 years from the issue of such notices. The validity of such notices was questioned. To save the validity of such notices the Amending Act was passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical context of notices challenged pre-1959; validates notices issued beyond time pre/post 1956 amendment, citing own prior decision in Prashar v. Vasantsen.

holdings.text: the appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail and are di-,missed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.4 validation to facts; no other points raised.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, though the numberices were served beyond the prescribed time, they were saved under s. 4 of the Amending Act. No other point was raised before us.
In the result, the appeals fail and are di-,missed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the emphasis on the letter of the law, the fundamental rule of construction of a fiscal Acts would apply, and not the exception engrafted on that rule for, s. 4 of the Amending Act cannot be described as a provision laying down the machinery for the calculation of tax. In substance it enables the Income-tax Officer to reassess a persons income which has escaped assessment, though the time within which he could have so assessed had expired under the Act before the amendment of 1959. It resuscitates barred claims.
In the result, the appeals fail and are di-,missed with companyts.

Further, the said expression has received, before the amendment, a clear judicial interpretation. Under s. 34 1 a of the Act the Income-tax Officer may in cases falling under cl. a at any time within 8 years serve on the assessee a notice... Rejecting that argument, Chagla, C. J., speaking for the Court, observed In other words, the attempt is to equate the expression served used in section 34 with the expression issued used in the proviso to sub- section 1 .
In the result, the appeals fail and are di-,missed with companyts.

Before the Amending Act of 1959 was passed, Income tax Officers issued notices before April 1, 1956, and also after that date for reopening assessments made beyond 8 years from the issue of such notices. The validity of such notices was questioned. To save the validity of such notices the Amending Act was passed.
In the result, the appeals fail and are di-,missed with companyts.
